target_title: Support XDG FileTransfer portal for Flatpak versions
Add built-in never-consent feature (like Firefox)

note.body: Probably the most popular webextension add-on for this nowadays is [Consent-O-Matic](https://consentomatic.au.dk/), which can be found as a Firefox, Chrome, Edge and Safari add-on… but it seems none of those extension repositories will let Epiphany install it.

target_title: Add bookmarks editing mode

note.body: Unfortunately it took much longer than I wanted, but I finally implemented the re-ordering, so this is ready for review again. Hopefully I didn't mess anything up :p

target_title: Pressing the FN key crashes the whole browser

note.body: YW. Sorry, I haven't used these debugging tools before :P

target_title: Pressing the FN key crashes the whole browser

note.body:
It's a WebKit bug, already fixed via https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=273780 but only because that bug reverts the fix for https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=261348, which introduced this crash. I've added a note to https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=261348 as a warning.

I'm a little nervous about backporting this change to 2.46, but it will be fixed in 2.48.

target_title: App crashing when using Web WhatsApp and other real time communication to a server sites

note.body: Thank you, I will read this and see if I can found more information

target_title: App crashing when using Web WhatsApp and other real time communication to a server sites

note.body: Thanks for taking the time to report this issue. Unfortunately, without a stack trace from the crash it's very hard to know what caused it. Please see [stack traces](https://handbook.gnome.org/issues/stack-traces.html) for more information on how to provide a stack trace.

target_title: Tab previews do not maintain their vertical height when dragged out of and then back into tab overview

note.body:
I'm not convinced. This is not an issue in Console, for instance. It is an issue in Tangram - the WebKitGTK-based browser with unique sandboxing features. The Adwaita Demo also does not have this issue. So, two WebKitGTK-based browsers have this issue, and two non-WebKitGTK apps using the AdwTabOverview don't have the issue.

target_title: Feature Request/ Improvement: After installing web app from current tab, display the current tab in a web app window

note.body:
> We cannot literally "move" the tab from the main profile to the web app profile

While that may be true from a strict / backend perspective (and I suppose that's what you meant), you still can cheat on visual perceptions, i.e. automatically open the web app window and close the tab in the previous main browser window. Even if the newly created web app doesn't inherit the internal data from the main browser's closed tab, it will still feel a bit more convenient; you could even automatically open the web app's preferences dialog so that the user can customize the name, additional allowed URLs, etc. right away.

target_title: open link in new tab moves selected tab out of focus

note.body:
> Why not leave the tab where it is and open the newly opened tab right next to it.

That is already mostly the behavior I am seeing in 47.2 on Fedora 41 (which is wonderful, because the previous behavior was very frustrating) "when there are not too many tabs open" (i.e. when the tabs "scale". If you open multiple tabs one after another they open "after the current tab, but in order".

I was intrigued so I tried reproducing OP's issue. It's a hard to tell by looking at the video above, because the video was not recorded with the mouse cursor activated, but I think part of the issue shown there is that in some overflow scenarios the tab strip scrolls to the end in a way that hides the current tab from the view when there are too many tabs open.

This video might show OP's issue better:

![2024-11-18_10-57-33](/uploads/a8caaa100536e9ae7925ee85d1757020/2024-11-18_10-57-33.mp4){width=100%}

Firefox solves this usability problem by not scrolling the tabs strip anymore when the currently selected tab has already been pushed to the edge, i.e. keeping the current tab in view at all times; in that case, it briefly flashes (in blue) the overflow indicator arrow instead as additional tabs keep getting added "off-screen":

![2024-11-18_11-08-31](/uploads/b643b0f18889db75b97c8518dc1d3e93/2024-11-18_11-08-31.mp4){width=100%}

target_title: Draft: Fix double font size when using text scaling

note.body: So I'm glad this works, but I'm pretty sure this API is being used as intended and needs to be fixed. I guess `webkit_settings_font_size_to_pixels()` will need to invert whatever DPI adjustment WebKit is performing. We don't want to have to adjust all applications that use this API, after all.

target_title: open link in new tab moves selected tab out of focus

note.body:
> Why not leave the tab where it is and open the newly opened tab right next to it.

We used to do that, and got complaints that tabs are opening backwards. Users in left-to-right locales expect tabs to open in left to right order.

target_title: open link in new tab moves selected tab out of focus

note.body:
I don't think that this behaviour could be intentional.

Why not leave the tab where it is and open the newly opened tab right next to it. A little bit moving is okay if the newly opened tab if not visible.

I think it should be handled like it is in Firefox and Chromium.

target_title: More seamless UI for web app mode

note.body:
In my opinion the most immediate changes that can be made to improve the UI are to remove the navigation buttons from the title bar and insert them into the main menu; in addition to this, it would also be preferable to remove the URL (always from the title bar) and to remove the URL preview that appears at the bottom left when you hover over a link.
These are immediate changes that can be made immediately, greatly improving the look and integration of web apps. Everything else can be added gradually in a targeted and rational way, always following the principles that distinguish GNOME UIs.

P.S. Personally I do not agree with the reduction of the thickness of the title bar, as all GNOME apps that integrate Libadwaita respect a standard thickness, equivalent for all windows; therefore it would be a deviation from the recent Libadwaita and GNOME UI.

target_title: WebApps crash when trying to select download location

note.body: The call to gtk_widget_get_root() in download_folder_row_activated_cb() is supposed to return a GtkWindow. Apparently in web app mode the toplevel is instead an AdwAlertDialog. And that is difficult to explain. I wonder what alert it is attempting to display....

target_title: Add built-in never-consent feature (like Firefox)

note.body: Your second reference indicates that Firefox is hardcoding support for [specific domains](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Nb4gVlGadyxix4i4FBDnOeT_eJp2Zcv69o-KfHtK-aA/edit?gid=0#gid=0). That's probably too sophisticated for Epiphany. The feature does seem pretty useful, but hardcoded workarounds just don't scale well at all.

target_title: Add bookmarks editing mode

note.body:
It's been two years since those designs and that thread; the edit mode concept was predicated on more edit and sort controls plus drag-and-drop ordering. After building this branch all that the Edit button seems to do is just toggle the Edit and Remove icons on each row which isn't a lot towards that goal.

A separate mode could be more justifiable if it also displayed drag handles to allow reordering bookmarks. I think this branch could just do with an popover menu on each bookmark that has the Remove and Edit actions in it.

target_title: Cannot delete web apps with apostrophe in name

note.body: Good find. We'll need to HTML-encode (or maybe JS-encode?) the web app name to prevent it from being executed. Probably not worth requesting a CVE since the user would have to agree to install a web app with a ridiculously suspicious name before there would be any security impact, but should still be fixed. I've audited this in the past, but maybe I didn't consider web app name should be treated as untrusted.

Stack trace of thread 3984:

It must be `set_focus()` from adw-dialog.c, and presumably `priv->focus_widget` must be invalid.

target_title: Epiphany crashes when entering country in "Autofill Data"

note.body: In general, we want to see a backtrace taken with gdb (as per the handbook instructions). But in this case, it's probably enough to see the bug is inside libadwaita's set_focus() function. Let's move to there.

target_title: Webkitgtk crash when printing as PostScript or SVG

note.body: I'm pretty sure PostScript and maybe also SVG are not actually supported by WebKit, so there's some mismatch between what GTK allows you to select and what WebKit can actually print. But it shouldn't crash.

target_title: Webkitgtk crash when printing as PostScript or SVG

note.body: Thanks for taking the time to report this issue. Unfortunately, without a stack trace from the crash it's very hard to know what caused it. Please see [stack traces](https://handbook.gnome.org/issues/stack-traces.html) for more information on how to provide a stack trace.

target_title: WebApps crash when trying to select download location

note.body:
You need to install debuginfo for GTK before taking the backtrace. Please also paste only the content _after_ `(gdb) bt full` .

In this case, you have a critical warning in your terminal (if running from a terminal) or your system journal (otherwise). Please paste that too. Thanks!

> **Only** if you do not have `systemd-coredump` installed on your system, instead follow https://wiki.gnome.org/GettingInTouch/Bugzilla/GettingTraces how to use `gdb` and also do make sure to install or compile debug symbols for the crashing application and the libraries used by it. In case you use Arch Linux, see https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Debug\\\_-\\\_Getting_Traces

I replaced https://wiki.gnome.org/GettingInTouch/Bugzilla/GettingTraces with a link to https://handbook.gnome.org/issues/stack-traces.html long ago, so this is not a useful canned reply. :)

Why?  
I only need one locale on my system, but spell-checking for several languages I use. I don't want to clutter my drive with tons of translations I'll never use. target_title: downloads popover stays open when an item is activated

note.body:
In #2517 @two noted:

> I would much rather find a solution which makes sure the popover doesn't grab focus, rather than relying on closing it as a workaround.

But I want to be clear, I don't see that as a workaround. It's just how a popover is supposed to behave. If you want it to stay open, don't use a popover.

It's unfortunate that the HIG doesn't specify here, but judging by its use in other situations, it makes sense for a popover to stay open if we can reasonably, _consistently_ expect for a user to continue interacting with its controls. Something you might click, look at the result, and continue clicking, like zoom or volume or playback speed.

We can't make that assumption here because on a smaller screen the popover isn't even in the foreground after we've opened a file.

Try it on a small laptop. (Or bump your display scaling to 300% if it's easier). Try opening more than one file from the downloads popover. And even when it is visible, if we get an open with dialog it won't be interactive.

target_title: The downloads popover should close when a file is opened

note.body:
I do, but that's what the open in folder button is for ;) Aside from the thing with my mouse that makes it worse, the trouble is an application has opened in the foreground in this case, but as long as the popover is open, that application won't work correctly.

A user could be rather dismayed if they find that the application doesn't respond to the mouse hovering over a button. (It'll look like it is frozen). Or, for example, the first thing they do could be to click and drag something, like a scrollbar, but the grab will prevent that from working correctly. Yes, it's fine when they click a second time, and (as a professional button pusher), I'm happy blindly clicking the mouse in a situation like that, but I know plenty of end users are not.

With that said, I realize the hardware I'm using is making this seem worse than it is :b

Anyway, I'm happy to send a patch (in a few days) if it's useful!

target_title: The downloads popover should close when a file is opened

note.body:
That's going to be pretty annoying whenever you want to open multiple files at once, though? Don't you ever download more than one thing at a time?

> Turns out with my mouse in particular (Logitech MX Master 3), clicking outside of an application _doesn't_ dismiss popovers.

I think you're doomed. :) We can't be changing user interface behavior as a workaround for this bug. (That's a pretty strange one... never heard of a particular mouse not working properly before.)

target_title: The downloads popover should close when a file is opened

note.body:
Incidentally, I learned about https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/-/issues/3414. Turns out with my mouse in particular (Logitech MX Master 3), clicking outside of an application _doesn't_ dismiss popovers. Which means that grab from Epiphany's popover becomes a serious problem.

For example in this situation…

![Screenshot_From_2024-11-04_17-09-33](/uploads/68dffcf7a4542b89b6add6a5f9c17f6b/Screenshot_From_2024-11-04_17-09-33.png)

… I can't interact with the Open With dialog, and (because it's a modal dialog) I can't actually interact with Epiphany to dismiss the popover either. I'm stuck until I press the Escape key.

That I'm _this_ stuck is a Mutter problem, but at the same time, that popover should probably have closed itself at this point.

target_title: Never open unsupported URLs

note.body:
Actually, checking !951, unfortunately that check was added for a reason:

> This code was originally added to prevent us from launching Epiphany in a recursive loop if it somehow gets registered as the default handler for a scheme that it doesn't actually support, as in #1053. In this case, we should only relaunch ourselves once because the second launch will be triggered by API request, when the new instance calls webkit_web_view_load_uri(). That's not a user gesture and will avoid the recursion.

So we shouldn't remove it unless we come up with some other way to avoid this.

note.body:
Well there is also another problem going on, it seems: even if I tell `dconf-editor` to recursively unset the keys of one of those web apps, it doesn't delete them, it resets them to their default values... which would tell me that there is still a dconf schema lingering around somewhere, I think? Otherwise resetting the keys would have deleted (in the absence of a schema), as far as I know.

Could it be that Epiphany web apps install schemas but Epiphany doesn't remove them when it deletes the web app (or if it does now, how do I check where they are located and how to remove them)?

target_title: Deleting a web app does not recursively reset / delete its gsettings dconf keys
Deleting a web app does not recursively reset / delete its gsettings dconf keys

note.body:
`gsettings reset-recursively` is a command line action. That's not part of the GSettings API for applications to use.

Epiphany also does not use dconf; that only gets used indirectly when not running under flatpak. It's one layer lower.

Barring any changes in GSettings APIs, I'm afraid you'll just need to get used to leaked settings keys.

note.body:
> […] It's really the central flaw in the design of web apps and it's been bothering me for over five years that nobody knows what to do about it. We're in a better position now than we were before because now it is possible for technically-minded users to whitelist URLs to open inside the web app, which was not the case until recently. But yes, most users will never know to do that.

My suggestion nowadays, in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/epiphany/-/issues/2039#note_1839534, would be:
* A whitelist of commonly used subdomain URLs patterns
* A temporary "app learning mode" (maybe with a prompt dialog for the user) to facilitate collecting/whitelisting URL domains before the user decides to "lock down" the app.

I bet this would solve the majority of problems.

target_title: Crash due to invalid url session store

note.body:
There are two cases:

 * We're in an iframe. Apparently the URI doesn't actually matter and Epiphany should be able to handle the load if only it didn't check whether the URI scheme is supported, #2475
 * We're not in an iframe. The load is doomed because Epiphany only supports https:// and http:// URIs, not `globalprotectcallback:` URIs. The page load must fail, and it should fail before Epiphany actually attempts to load it, to prevent it from ever reaching the session state.

target_title: Deleting a web app does not recursively reset / delete its gsettings dconf keys

note.body:
> There's no way to do this with GSettings, so we'd have to interact directly with the settings backends.

At least a command line exists, I think `gsettings reset-recursively SCHEMA*[:*PATH]` (found [here](https://man.archlinux.org/man/gsettings.1)) does delete (IIRC) the things being reset if they have no schema set by the system, no? Is there an equivalent for that programmatically?

target_title: Deleting a web app does not recursively reset / delete its gsettings dconf keys

note.body:
There's no way to do this with GSettings, so we'd have to interact directly with the settings backends.

For host settings, we could use dconf directly, except I'm not sure how. The dconf API is not really designed to be used by applications.

For Flatpak, we could do manual deletion of the settings keyfiles, except it's not really necessary because GNOME Software allows users to decide whether to delete stored configuration data or not.

note.body:
It seems to randomly happen most of the time when you try to launch Fedora 41's MiniBrowser with sysprof, too, with this command for example:

`sysprof-cli --gtk -f -- /usr/libexec/webkitgtk-6.0/MiniBrowser --private https://www.apple.com/iphone-16-pro/`

In my case, with that command, either it:
* Works normally
* The MiniBrowser process doesn't start at all, never shows up
* The MiniBrowser process starts and is in a "sleeping" state (according to gnome-system-monitor) and _never_ shows up (I waited 5 minutes).

Maybe that could make it occur on Michael's computers.

target_title: Searching in history panel deselects all items and doesn't make delete button insensitive, allowing you to press it and cause a crash
Reader mode should have its own zoom level, independent of each original page

note.body:
Testing with version 47.0 (and previous versions in recent years), this does not seem to work.

1. Enter reader mode.
2. Change zoom level
3. Exit reader mode: the non-reader mode page's zoom has been changed
4. Reset that zoomed page to 100% with `Ctrl+0`
5. Re-enter reader mode: its zoom level was reset.
6. Re-zoom the reader mode
7. Switch to another tab, enter reader mode in that tab. Result: that tab's zoom level is 100% (or whatever the tab's zoom level is) instead of sharing the zoom level across reader mode instances no matter the tab.

This doesn't seem different to me than the original report here. Could we simply reopen this ticket, or this needs to be filed as a new ticket?

target_title: The text is too compact in reader mode

note.body: I think one way to solve a big part of this would be for zoom to actually work independently in reader mode. It was supposed to in #50, but it doesn't.
